citations.title: Clinical Pharmacogenetics Implementation Consortium guidelines for HLA-B genotype and carbamazepine dosing.

sentences.text: Clinical Pharmacogenetics Implementation Consortium (CPIC) Guidelines for HLA-B Genotype and Carbamazepine Dosing

citations.summary: Human leukocyte antigen B (HLA-B) is a gene that encodes a cell surface protein involved in presenting antigens to the immune system. The variant allele HLA-B*15:02 is associated with an increased risk of Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) in response to carbamazepine treatment. We summarize evidence from the published literature supporting this association and provide recommendations for the use of carbamazepine based on HLA-B genotype (also available on PharmGKB: http://www.pharmgkb.org). The purpose of this article is to provide information to allow the interpretation of clinical HLA-B*15:02 genotype tests so that the results can be used to guide the use of carbamazepine. The guideline provides recommendations for the use of carbamazepine when HLA-B*15:02 genotype results are available. Detailed guidelines regarding the selection of alternative therapies, the use of phenotypic tests, when to conduct genotype testing, and cost-effectiveness analyses are beyond the scope of this document. Clinical Pharmacogenetics Implementation Consortium (CPIC) guidelines are published and updated periodically on the PharmGKB website at (http://www.pharmgkb.org).

summaryMarkdown.html: The CPIC Dosing Guideline for oxcarbazepine recommends an alternative drug for oxcarbazepine-naive patients carrying at least one copy of HLA-B*15:02 due to the association of this allele with an increased risk of Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN).

textMarkdown.html:
This annotation is based on the CPIC® guideline for oxcarbazepine and HLA-B.

December 2017

Accepted article preview online January 2018; Advance online publication February 2018.

  • The 2017 update of CPIC guidelines regarding the use of pharmacogenomic tests in dosing of carbamazepine expanded to include information on pharmacogenomic tests in dosing of oxcarbazepine. The updated guidelines were published in Clinical Pharmacology and Therapeutics by the Clinical Pharmacogenetics Implementation Consortium (CPIC). Literature up to June 2016 was reviewed, recommendations and supplemental information were updated.
  • Excerpts from the 2017 dosing guideline update:
    • "There is evidence linking HLA-B*15:02 genotype with the risk of carbamazepine- and oxcarbazepine-induced SJS/TEN."
    • "Data describing the relationship between HLA-B*15:02 and HLA-A*31:01 genotype and carbamazepine- or oxcarbazepine-induced cutaneous adverse reactions in pediatric patients are scarce. In the absence of data suggesting a different relationship between these HLA alleles and drug-induced hypersensitivity in pediatric patients, the recommendations may be used to guide use of carbamazepine and oxcarbazepine in both adult and pediatric patients."
